sources.title: KennelMurderCase1933
sources.description: Philo Vance investigates one of his most famous locked-room murders.

sources.title: TheKennelMurderCase720p1933
sources.description: Title: The Kennel Murder Case Summary: Philo Vance, accompanied by his prize-losing Scottish terrier, investigates the locked-room murder of a prominent and much-hated collector whose broken Chinese vase provides an important clue. Directed by: Michael Curtiz Actors: William Powell, Mary Astor, Eugene Pallette Production Company: Warner Bros. Release Date: 28 October 1933 (USA) Aspect Ratio: 1.37 : 1 Archer Coe has been found dead in his locked bedroom. The cops consider it suicide, but Philo believes otherwise. When the Coroner shows up, he finds that Archer had been hit with a blunt object, stabbed and shot - making suicide unlikely. When the evidence points to his brother, Brisbane is found stabbed to death in the closet. Archer had a number of enemies, any one of which would have been glad to knock him off, but which one did and how did the murder occur in a room looked from the inside. Only one man, the keen, fascinating, debonair detective Philo Vance, would be able to figure out who is the killer.

sources.title: The Kennel Murder Case
sources.description: Philo Vance interrupts a trip to Italy to investigate the murder of a fellow dog fancier. Stars: William Powell, Mary Astor, Eugene Pallette, Ralph Morgan, and Robert McWade IMDb Page this movie can also be found here .

sources.title: The Kennel Murder Case (1933) | Colorized Public Domain Classic Mystery with William Powell
sources.description:
The Kennel Murder Case (1933) is a pre-Code American mystery directed by Michael Curtiz and adapted from S.S. Van Dine‚Äôs celebrated detective novel. This restored and colorized version brings fresh life to one of the finest Philo Vance mysteries, showcasing William Powell in one of his last performances as the suave detective before he went on to fame in The Thin Man series. Known for its sharp direction, clever plotting, and Curtiz‚Äôs stylish cinematic touch, this film is considered a landmark in early Hollywood detective cinema.

Plot Summary:
Set against the backdrop of New York‚Äôs elite social scene, the story opens with Archer Coe, a wealthy and domineering dog fancier, found dead in his locked bedroom. Initially declared a suicide, the case quickly grows suspicious when detective Philo Vance (William Powell) begins to investigate.

As Vance digs deeper, he uncovers a complex web of jealousy, rivalry, greed, and hidden secrets within the Coe household. Multiple suspects emerge, from Archer‚Äôs estranged family to his business associates and even those within his world of competitive dog breeding. Each twist reveals new motives and alibis, leading to one of the cleverest ‚Äúlocked room mystery‚Äù resolutions in detective fiction. With wit, charm, and razor-sharp deduction, Vance unravels the case and exposes the true culprit in classic mystery fashion.

Cast and Crew:
‚Ä¢ Director: Michael Curtiz
‚Ä¢ Screenplay: Robert N. Lee, based on the novel by S.S. Van Dine
‚Ä¢ Cinematography: William Rees
‚Ä¢ Editing: George Amy
‚Ä¢ Studio/Distributor: Warner Bros.

Starring:
‚Ä¢ William Powell as Philo Vance
‚Ä¢ Mary Astor as Hilda Lake
‚Ä¢ Eugene Pallette as Sergeant Heath
‚Ä¢ Ralph Morgan as Raymond Wrede
‚Ä¢ Robert Barrat as Archer Coe
‚Ä¢ Paul Cavanagh as Sir Thomas MacDonald
‚Ä¢ Helen Vinson as Doris Delafield
‚Ä¢ Frank Conroy as Grassi
‚Ä¢ Etienne Girardot as Dr. Doremus

Film Significance:
The Kennel Murder Case is widely praised as one of the best Philo Vance mysteries ever filmed, with critics and historians noting its brisk pacing, stylish camera work, and William Powell‚Äôs magnetic performance. Michael Curtiz‚Äôs direction foreshadows the visual mastery he would later bring to classics such as Casablanca. The movie also exemplifies the pre-Code era‚Äôs boldness, with themes of greed, betrayal, and moral corruption depicted without restraint. For fans of detective stories, locked-room mysteries, and Golden Age Hollywood, this film remains an essential watch.

Enhanced Public Domain Explanation:
This film is in the public domain, which means it is completely free of copyright restrictions and can be legally shared, viewed, studied, and preserved without limitation. Colorized Public Domain restores and enhances these historic works through careful digital cleaning, visual restoration, and colorization techniques. Our mission is to ensure that timeless classics like The Kennel Murder Case remain available to a worldwide audience. By presenting them in color and modern quality, we make them more engaging and accessible to younger generations who might otherwise overlook black-and-white cinema. This process respects the original film while providing a new layer of appreciation for today‚Äôs viewers.

Why Watch This Colorized Edition:
The original 1933 release was filmed in black-and-white, as was standard for its time. While historically authentic, black-and-white films are often overlooked by modern audiences. This colorized edition bridges the gap between preservation and accessibility, enhancing William Powell‚Äôs final turn as Philo Vance while making the intricate mystery more approachable for today‚Äôs viewers in the United States, Europe, and beyond.

metadata.Plot: Archer Coe has been found dead in his locked bedroom. The cops consider it suicide, but Philo believes otherwise. When the Coroner shows up, he finds that Archer had been hit with a blunt object, stabbed and shot - making suicide unlikely. When the evidence points to his brother, Brisbane is found stabbed to death in the closet. Archer had a number of enemies, any one of which would have been glad to knock him off, but which one did and how did the murder occur in a room looked from the inside. Only one man, the keen, fascinating, debonair detective Philo Vance, would be able to figure out who is the killer.
